Advice Content: At night, discuss with your child what the next morning's activities will be. For example, what time to wake up, what to eat for breakfast, what to wear, etc. This will help your child start thinking about planning for the next day so they are better prepared when they wake up and not worrying about what decisions to make.

Make a list of simple steps for getting ready and post it on the wall. This will be your child's "to-do list" for when they wake up in the morning. This frees up their mental bandwidth and makes it less likely they'll get distracted or miss a key step.
Create a visual bedtime to-do list so your child knows at a glance what they need to do. This will free up their mental bandwidth so they don't need to stress about what to do before bed.

If your child has cravings while you're out, offer alternatives, such as, "I can't buy you a snack right now, but let's make something tasty together when we get home." This will give your child an alternative to look forward to.

Divide homework into small tasks and create a checklist for each one. This will help your child understand exactly what they need to do and they will feel a sense of accomplishment when they finish by checking it off or crossing it off the list.
